channel.title: Job on Christian Internet Resources
channel.description: Recent content in Job on Christian Internet Resources

item.title: Job 1
item.description:
Job Chapter 1

1Job lived in the land of Uz, a blameless, godly man that respected God and shunned evil. 2He had seven sons and three daughters; 3and

owned 7

,000 sheep, 3,000 camels, 500 yoke of oxen, 500 female donkeys; and many servants. 4His sons would hold feasts in each other’s houses and invite their three sisters. 5When the feasting days had completed their cycle, Job would consecrate them, getting up early and offering burnt offerings for each one, “Maybe my children have sinned and cursed God in their hearts.”

6One day when the sons of God came to present themselves to Yahveh, Satan came too. 7Yahveh asked him, “Where’d you come from?” “From roaming around in the world.” 8“Have you noticed my servant Job? There’s nobody in the world like him, a blameless, godly man that respects me and shuns evil.” 9“Does he respect you for nothing? 10Haven’t you planted a hedge around him, his home, and everything he owns? You’ve blessed his work, and his possessions have increased in the world. 11Reach out and touch everything he has, and he’ll curse you to your face.” 12“Everything he has is under your authority. Just don’t do anything to him.” So Satan left.

item.title: Job 2
item.description:
Job Chapter 2

1On another day when the sons of God came to present themselves to Yahveh, Satan came with them. 2Yahveh asked him, “Where’d you come from?” “From roaming around in the world.” 3“Have you noticed my servant Job? There’s nobody like him in the world, a blameless, godly man that respects me and shuns evil. He still maintains his integrity, even though you incited me against him to ruin him for no reason.” 4“Skin for skin! Everything mortalsm have they’ll give for their life. 5Reach out and touch his flesh and bone, and he’ll curse you to your face.” 6“He’s under your authority. Just don’t take his life.”

item.title: Job 3
item.description:
Job Chapter 3

1Afterward Job cursed the day he was born: [2] 3“Perish the day I was born, the night I was conceived.

4May that be a dark day; let God above not care about it or any light shine on it.

5Let darkness and gloom claim it, dark clouds cover it, and darkness make it terrifying.

6Let darkness seize that night; let it not celebrate among the days of the year or be counted among the months.

item.title: Job 4
item.description:
Job Chapter 4

1Eliphaz the Temanite answered: 2“Will you be offended if someone offers you advice? Who can help speaking up?

3You’ve admonished many people and encouraged the weak.

4What you’ve said has helped the tottering stand and weak knees hold firm.

5But now difficulty has come to you, and you’re impatient and distressed.

6Isn’t your reverence for God your confidence, and the integrity of your ways your hope?

item.title: Job 5
item.description:
Job Chapter 5

1“Call out for help now; will anybody answer you? Which of the angels will you turn to?

2Adversity slays the foolish; anger kills the simpleminded.

3I’ve seen the foolish taking root and having their progress immediately cursed.

4Their children are never safe, they’re oppressed in the courts, and there’s nobody to deliver them.

5The hungry eat up their harvest; briers take over it; schemers are eager to get their wealth;

item.title: Job 6
item.description:
Job Chapter 6

1Job answered: 2“Oh that my adversity was properly weighed in the balances with my sins!

3 3It would outweigh the sand by the seashore; that’s why I’ve been rash.

4The arrows of the Almighty are piercing me; my spirit is absorbing their poison; God’s terrors are attacking me.

5Does a wild donkey bray when it has grass? Does an ox bawl over its hay?

item.title: Job 7
item.description:
Job Chapter 7

1“Aren’t people forced into hard labor? Aren’t their days like those of a hired hand?

2Like a slave panting for shade, like an employee waiting for wages,

3 3I’ve been allotted months of emptiness and given restless nights.

4When I‘m in bed, I say, ‘When is morning ever going to get here?’ But night goes on and on, and I toss and turn till dawn.

item.title: Job 8
item.description:
Job Chapter 8

1Bildad the Shuhite answered: 2“How long will you talk like that? You make your mouth a blustering wind?

3Does God pervert justice? Does the Almighty twist the truth?

4When your children sinned against him, he delivered them to the consequences of their sin.

5If you look for God and beg for mercy from the Almighty,

6 6if you’re pure and just, he’ll certainly act on your behalf and restore you to your good position.

item.title: Job 9
item.description:
Job Chapter 9

1Job answered: 2“I know that’s true, but how can anyone be innocent in God’s sight?

3If you wanted to dispute with him, you couldn’t answer him once in a thousand times.

4He’s so wise and powerful; who has ever defied him and succeeded?

Job 9:1-4

5“It’s God that moves mountains; they don’t know it when he overturns them in his anger.

6He can shake the earth and make its pillars tremble;

item.title: Job 10
item.description:
Job Chapter 10

1“I detest my life; so I’ll fully vent my complaint and speak out of my total frustration.

2I’ll tell God, ‘Don’t just condemn me; tell me why you’re contending with me.

3Is it right for you to oppress me, to reject my toil, to look favorably on sinners’ schemes?

4Do you just have physical eyes and only see like people see?

5Are your days like a mortal’s, your years like a human’s,

item.title: Job 11
item.description:
Job Chapter 11

1Zophar the Naamathite answered: 2“Should your barrage of words go unchallenged, and you exonerate yourself by talking a lot?

3Will your babble shut people up? Will you mock and nobody rebuke you?

4You claim your beliefs are pure and you’re innocent in God’s presence;

5but I just wish God would speak out against you

6 6and disclose to you the secrets of wisdom, because sound wisdom is not simple; be assured that God doesn’t remember just one part of your sin.

item.title: Job 12
item.description:
Job Chapter 12

1Job answered: 2“No doubt, you’re the people, and wisdom will die with you!

3But I’m as smart as you are; I’m not your inferior. Who doesn’t know things like that?

4I’m a laughingstock to my friends, one who called on God and he answered, a just and blameless man; yet I’m a laughingstock.

5In the thoughts of people at ease, there’s contempt for disaster; they’re ready to give a shove to those whose feet are slipping.

item.title: Job 13
item.description:
Job Chapter 13

1“I’ve seen that; I’ve heard it and understand it.

2What you know, I know too; I’m not more ignorant than you.

Job 13:1-2

3“But I’m willing to speak to the Almighty himself; I want to argue with God.

4You men are smearing me with things that aren’t true; you’re untrained doctors.

5Oh that you’d just be quiet and show your wisdom that way!

item.title: Job 14
item.description:
Job Chapter 14

1“Mortals born of women are short-lived and filled with turmoil.

2They come out and wither like a flower; they pass away like a shadow and don’t last.

3You keep your eyes open at them and bring them under your judgment.

4Who can make unclean into clean? Nobody!

5Since their days are set, you determine the number of their months and set limits they can’t pass.

item.title: Job 15
item.description:
Job Chapter 15

1Eliphaz the Temanite answered: 2“Should you answer with empty talk and fill yourself with the east wind?

3Should you argue with useless speech, with words that do no good?

4You’re losing reverence for God and hindering meditation in front of him.

5Your sin is telling you what you say, and you’re choosing misleading language.

6You condemn yourself; I don’t; you’re testifying against yourself.

item.title: Job 16
item.description:
Job Chapter 16

1Job answered: 2“I’ve heard a lot of things like that; you’re miserable comforters.

3Is there no end to windy words? What’s your problem that you answer me like that?

4I could talk to you like you’re talking if I was in your place. I could string out words and shake my head at you.

5Or, I could encourage you so my comfort could lessen your pain.

item.title: Job 17
item.description:
Job Chapter 17

1My spirit’s broken; my days are snuffed out; people have already dug my grave.

2Mockers sit around and taunt me to my face.

Job 16:18-17

:2 3“God, sign a pledge for me; who else will put up security for me?

4You’ve kept them from understanding; so don’t let them triumph.

5They inform against their friends to get a share of their property; so let their children pass out from hunger.

item.title: Job 18
item.description:
Job Chapter 18

1Bildad the Shuhite answered: 2“How long will you stumble around for words? Make some sense so we can talk.

3Why do you treat us like animals? You think we’re stupid?

4Are you going to tear yourself to pieces in your anger? Are we supposed to leave the world for fear of you? Should ledge rocks quake out of place? 5“The light of the wicked goes out; their flame stops giving light.

item.title: Job 19
item.description:
Job Chapter 19

1Job answered: 2“How long are you going to torment me and shatter me with a barrage of words?

3You’ve insulted me ten times over; aren’t you ashamed of treating me wrong?

4Even if I did make mistakes, that’s on me.

5If you’re acting superior to me and using my humiliation to argue against me,

6 6know that God is the One that’s put me in the wrong and closed his net around me.

item.title: Job 20
item.description:
Job Chapter 20

1Zophar the Naamathite answered: 2“My thoughts make me answer because I’m in turmoil inside.

3I’ve listened to your insults, and I’m answering from what I understand.

4Don’t you know from of old— from the time God put people on earth—

5 5that the triumph of sinners is short-lived; the joy of the godless is temporary.

Job 20:1-5

6Though they’re as tall as the sky, though their heads are in the clouds,

item.title: Job 21
item.description:
Job Chapter 21

1Job answered: 2“Listen carefully; let this be your consolation.

3Bear with me; after I’ve spoken, you can mock me.

4Am I just complaining about people? Why shouldn’t I be impatient?

5Be appalled at the way I look; put your hand over your mouth in shock.

6When I think about it, I get scared and shaky.

7Why do bad people keep on living and become so powerful?

item.title: Job 22
item.description:
Job Chapter 22

1Eliphaz the Temanite answered. 2“What benefit can a mortal be to God? Aren’t even the wise only useful to themselves?

3Is the Almighty delighted if you’re good? What good is it to him if you’re perfect?

4Surely it’s not because you revere him that he’s reproving you, that he’s bringing judgment against you.

5Isn’t it more likely that you’re sinful, that your sins are endless?

6Maybe you’ve exacted pledges from your friends and stripped off their clothes as security.

item.title: Job 23
item.description:
Job Chapter 23

1Job answered: 2“My complaint is still bitter; God’s hand weighs heavily on me despite my groaning.

3If only I knew where to find him so I could go to his courtroom!

4I’d present my case and offer my arguments.

5I’d find out what he’d answer and understand what he’d say.

6Would he oppose me with his great power? No, he’d listen!

7Someone godly would be reasoning with him, and my Judge would acquit me permanently.

item.title: Job 24
item.description:
Job Chapter 24

1“Why doesn’t the Almighty maintain a regular court schedule for judging? Why do those who know him wait for him in vain?

2Some remove landmarks, seize flocks and eat them,

3drive away donkeys that belong to the fatherless, take widows’ oxen for pledges.

4They run the needy off the road; the poor people have to hide from them.

5Like wild donkeys in the desert, the poor labor at foraging for food, looking for prey in the wild to feed their children.

item.title: Job 25
item.description:
Job Chapter 25

1Bildad the Shuhite answered: 2“Dominion and awe belong to God, who establishes order high in his sky.

3Who can count his troops? Who doesn’t his light rise on?

4How can anyone be innocent in his presence? How can anyone born of woman be pure?

5If the moon isn’t bright and the stars aren’t pure to God,

6how much less people—like maggots, and their offspring—mere worms.”

Job 25:1-6

item.title: Job 26
item.description:
Job Chapter 26

1Job answered: 2“What a help you are to the weak! How you’ve saved arms with no strength!

3What counsel you’ve given me in my stupidity! What brilliant insight you’ve provided!

4Who’ve you been talking to? Whose spirit has been speaking through you?!

Job 26:1-4

5“The departed spirits tremble below the water and its inhabitants.

6Sheol is naked in front of him; Abaddon has no covering before him.

item.title: Job 27
item.description:
Job Chapter 27

1Job continued his comments: 2“As God lives, who has taken away my rights, the Almighty, who has made me bitter,

3as long as I’m alive and God’s breath is in me,

4I won’t speak wickedness or lie.

5I’ll never concede that you’re right; I’ll defend my integrity till I die.

6I’ll hold onto my claim about my goodness, and my conscience won’t accuse me for it.

item.title: Job 28
item.description:
Job Chapter 28

1“There’s a mine for silver and a refinery for gold.

2Iron comes out of the ground, and people can smelt copper.

3They use a torch in the darkness and go in as far they can, searching for the ore in gloom and deep shadow.

4They sink mine shafts far from where people live and go down them, dangling on ropes, swinging back and forth.

5People grow food on top of the ground; but far below, the ground melts as if by fire.

item.title: Job 29
item.description:
Job Chapter 29

1Job took up his discourse again: 2“Oh that I could be like I was just a few months ago when God was watching over me,

3when his lamp shined above my head and I walked through darkness by his light,

4while I was in the prime of life and his friendship hovered above my tent,

5when the Almighty was still with me and my children were around me,

item.title: Job 30
item.description:
Job Chapter 30

:1“But now people younger than me make fun of me, people whose fathers I wouldn’t let run with my sheep dogs.

2What good was their strength to me, fellows whose vigor was gone?

3They were haggard from hunger and want and clawed the dry ground in the wastelands.

4They picked wild greens from among the bushes and ate the roots of broom shrubs.

5People drove them away; they shouted at them like they were thieves.

item.title: Job 31
item.description:
Job Chapter 31

1“I’ve made a covenant with my eyes not to look with lust at a young woman?

2What is our portion from God above, our inheritance from the Almighty on high?

3Isn’t it misfortune for the unjust, disaster for sinners?

4Doesn’t he see everything I do and count every step I take? 5“If I’ve supposedly conducted myself falsely and tried to deceive,

6let him weigh me with accurate scales and he’ll find out my integrity.

item.title: Job 32
item.description:
Job Chapter 32

1The three men stopped replying to Job, because he was certain he was innocent. 2Then Elihu Ben-Barachel the Buzite from the family of Ram, was mad at Job because he’d justified himself to God. 3He was mad at his three friends because they couldn’t answer Job but still condemned him. 4Elihu had waited to speak because they were years older than he was. 5When he saw they didn’t provide an answer, his anger burned inside him. 6So he spoke up. “I’m young and you’re old; so I’ve been reluctant to tell you what I believed.

item.title: Job 33
item.description:
Job Chapter 33

1“But now, Job, listen to what I have to say; hear me out.

2I’m opening my mouth now; the tongue in my mouth is speaking.

3What I’m saying expresses my uprightness; my lips declare knowledge sincerely.

4The Spirit of God has made me; the breath of the Almighty gives me breath.

5Answer me if you can; state your case; take your stand.

6I belong to God like you do; I’ve been formed out of clay too.

item.title: Job 34
item.description:
Job Chapter 34

1Elihu continued: 2“Listen, you wise men; pay attention, you that ‘know’;

3the ear tests words like the palate tastes food.

4Let’s choose what’s right; let’s determine for ourselves what’s good;

5because Job has said, ‘I’m good, but God has disregarded my goodness.

6Should I lie about my goodness? I have a wound that won’t heal, but I haven’t done anything wrong.’

7Who is like Job that drinks scorn like water,

item.title: Job 35
item.description:
Job Chapter 35

1Elihu continued: 2“Do you think it’s righteous for you to say you’re upright before God?

3You say, ‘What advantage will I have? What benefit will I get more than if I’d sinned?’

4I’ll answer you and your friends.

5Look at the sky; the clouds are higher than you are.

6If you’ve sinned, what do you gain against God? if you have lots of sins, what harm are you doing to him?

item.title: Job 36
item.description:
Job Chapter 36

1Elihu continued: 2“Bear with me a little longer, and I’ll show you what I have to say on God’s behalf.

3I’ll bring my knowledge from afar and credit goodness to my Maker.

4What I’m saying is true; I know perfectly well what I’m talking about.

5God is powerful, but he doesn’t despise anybody; he’s mighty in his power to understand.

6He doesn’t keep sinners alive, but gives justice to the oppressed.

item.title: Job 37
item.description:
Job Chapter 37

1“My heart pounds when I think about this; it feels like it’s out of place.

2Listen closely to his thundering, the rumbling that comes from his mouth.

3He unleashes his lightning under the whole sky; it travels to the horizon in every direction.

4After it his roars; he thunders with his majestic voice and doesn’t hold anything back.

5God thunders wondrously and does extraordinary things we can’t comprehend.

item.title: Job 38
item.description:
Job Chapter 38

1God answered Job out of the whirlwind: 2“Who is this that confuses my counsel with ignorant words?

3Gird up* like a man; I’ll ask you some questions, and you answer me.

4Where were you when I laid the foundation for the earth? Tell me if you have any idea.

5Who specified its measurements or stretched out a line on it? Surely you know!

6What did its pylons rest on? Who laid its cornerstone

item.title: Job 39
item.description:
Job Chapter 39

1“Do you know when mountain goats give birth? Do you ever see a deer calving?

2Can you count the months of their gestation or learn when they have their fawns?

3They crouch down to deliver their young.

4Their offspring grow strong out in the open; they leave home and never return.

Job 39:1-4

5“Who turned the wild donkey loose? Who untied its ropes?

6I gave it the open country for a home, desert land to live in?

item.title: Job 40
item.description:
Job Chapter 40

1Yahveh said to Job, 2“Will a faultfinder spar with the Almighty? Let the one that argues with God answer that.”

3Job said, 4“I’m insignificant; what kind of answer can I give? I’ve put my hand over my mouth.

5I’ve spoken once or twice; that’s enough; I don’t have anything else to say.”

Job 40:1-5

6Yahveh answered him out of the storm: 7“Gird up* like a man; I’ll ask you some questions, and you answer me.

item.title: Job 41
item.description:
Job Chapter 41

:1“Can you pull Leviathan in on a fishhook or muzzle it with a noose?

2Can you tie it up with a rope in its nose or pierce its jaw with a hook?

3Will it beg you for mercy or speak to you softly?

4Will it agree to work for you like a slave for life?

5Will you make a pet out of it like a bird or put it on a leash for your little girls?

item.title: Job 42
item.description:
Job Chapter 42

1Job answered Yahveh: 2“I know you can do anything and nobody can thwart what you do.

3You asked, ‘Who is this that darkens my counsel with ignorance?’ So I admit I don’t understand; these things are too awesome for me to look into.

4You said, ‘Listen; I’ll talk; I’ll ask; you instruct me.’

5I’d only heard about you before, but now I see you.
